Be Just and Fear Not.

Friday, Octobeb 1G, 1896.

Hon. members of the Legislative Assembly have now before them the State Bank Bill introduced by the Government, and the public will watch with the keenest interest

the manner in which their repre sentatives deal with so important a subject. It -is now many years since the proposal for the establish

ment of a State Bank in Victoria was first mooted; but it appeared to have been lost sight of during the land and silver booms, when the necessity for any such institu tion was not felt by those who were accumulating vast fortunes— on paper—through the medium of the syndicates that, with members

of Parliament at the head of their directorates, dealt with thousands in a much lighter manner than the ordinary citizen in these days re gards a single pound. But the

stress of the times has sobered us and caused us to indulge in cool and calm reflection ; and our legislators give recognition to the

fact that the first aid to the further development of the resources of the country must be cheap money. The Government Bill, we are told, is drawn with the double object of establishing a State Bank and amalgamating the Post-office and Commissioners’ Savings - banks. That step has, of course, every thing to commend it; indeed, it would be absurd to have running at one and the same time three

separate and distinct institutions, practically under the one head. The-measure provides for raising by mortgage bonds a fund to be placed at the disposal of the Com missioners of Savings-banks for advances; for making advances at

reasonable rates, on convenient terms, and upon proper securities ; and for keeping separate and dis tinct accounts relating to the Savings-bank department, the ad vances department, and the issue and banking branch of the State Bank, which it is arranged shall have the following general powers : To receive money on current account and invest the same as

hereafter mentioned, and to repay ! the same without interest; to establish agencies of the bank at any post-office or elsewhere in Vic

toria or in London; to act as banker for any other bank; to purchase, take on lease, or other wise acquire, and sell, demise or otherwise dispose of for the pur pose of carrying on the business of the bank, any real or personal property; to maintain, repair and improve any real or personal property of the bank; and to exercise all such incidental powers as shall be necessary to carry on the business of the bank, which is to be managed by the Savings-banks commissioners, who in payment of their services are to receive a guinea a meeting, but no commissioner is to get more than ^105 in a year for attendance fees. An inspector-general, at a salary of £1000 per annum, is to be ap pointed. The State Bank is to hold all Government moneys and the State account, and may issue notes ranging in value from 10s to^ioo, which notes will not be liable to duty and are made legal tender. A branch of the bank is to be established for the reception of current accounts, which may be operated on by cheque; and cor porations and societies are per

mitted to have current accounts

with the bank, but no interest is to be allowed thereon. When ap praising the actual value of any property, valuators are to carefully consider its clear income-earning capacity utilised for pastoral or agricultural purposes in average seasons and markets, having due regard to depreciation where ne cessary, and the cost of such arti ficial fertilisers as may be necessary to prevent appreciable depreciation in the quality and value of the land. The total appraised actual value of such property shall in no case exceed (a) twenty-five times the clear annual income earning capacity of the land in the case of land used exclusively for pastoral purposes, nor (b) twenty times the clear annual income-earniDg capa city of the land in the case of land used for agricultural purposes. In the case of land which has acquired a special increase of value by reason of being cultivated as vine yards, hop grounds, orchards or fruit growing plantations, or for other like purposes, the ’value of such land shall be based upon its clear income-earning capacity if utilised for the production of ordi nary cereal, pulse or root crops, or for pastoral purposes. Having given these few details as to the nature of the Bill, we await with much interest the deliberations of hon. members to whom the Premier has set no light task in giving due consideration to the pro visions of a measure that is the most intricate that has of late years been placed before them.

The Tatura Show.—We have again to remind our readers of the Tatura Show, which takes place next Wednesday and Thursday. The entries are large in all classes, and some of the finest exhibits ever brought into a show-ground in the district will be on view. Many novel and interesting features will this year be intro duced, the committee and their energetic secretary, Mr Luke Flanagan, being fully alive to the fact that the more attrac tions they can offer to the public the greater is the interest taken in the show. On the first day there will be a chaffcutting contest, sheep-dog trials, and other addi tions to the ordinary show programme ; while the trials of hunters and pony jumping promise this year to be particu larly good, some first-class animals being engaged. The second day witnesses the attendance of His Excellency the Governor, Lady Brassey, and suite, who will arrive by special train, accompanied by a large Parliamentary party, including members of both Houses. The attendance bids fair to he exceptionally large, and as on Thurs day the weekly half-holiday will be observed in Shepparton (in place of Wed nesday) tlie number of visitors from this district will be a substantial increase upon those attending in former years. An im portant feature of the show will be an educational exhibit by the Department of Agriculture, Mr. Robilliard, Government expert, having been in Tatura on Tuesday, making arrangements for the display 'of essential oils, seeds of all kinds, flax, fibre, tobacco leaf, &e., for which a space of 60 x 60ft. has been allotted.

Minor Offences.—At the Police Court on Tuesday, before Messrs. Ford, Caldwell, and Thom. J's.P., two parents were fined 10s each for not having their children vaccinated, and a third case of a like nature was adjourned for fourteen days. For neglecting to send their children to school the required number of days, two local residents were called upon to contribute half-a-crown apiece.

The N.S.W. Land Rcsh,—A Corowa telegram on Wednesday stated :—The town is crowded to-night with intending ap plicants for two blocks of 400 acres each at Boomanoomana, which are open for homestead selections. A dozen or more agents are driving a lucrative business filling up forms at 2s 6d each, and they estimate the number of applicants at fully 1000. Mr Gale, the land agent, has had barricades erected on the verandah of the courthouse, for the protection of the build ing, ns on a former occasion the mad rush of people caused great damage to Govern ment property. Fully 70 per cent, of the applicants are. from Victoria. All the hotels are crowded, and constant streams of vehicles arc coming by all roads converg ing on Corowa. The result of the ballot will not be made known for probably a

Entertainment.—This evening at the Fruitgrowers’ Hall, Ardmona, a concert will be given in aid of the funds of the Church of England. A splendid programme has been arranged, and Mr and Mrs Otto Brandon will play the popular and amusing comedietta, “My Milliner’s Bill.”

AN Unfortunate Occurrence.—Mr

J. E. Dyass on Tuesday morning had the misfortune to lose a valuable buggy horse (one of his handsome pair of chestnuts) in a singular manner. The two horses were running loose in the yard of his residence in Edwardstrect, and in attempting to jump the picket fence one of them became impaled, and was so badly injured that it had to be destroyed.

The Cibcus.—Shepparton is on Tues day next to be favored with a visit from FitzGerald Bros.’ circus and menagerie, and that evening an entertainment of a very comprehensive and first-class descrip tion will be given, the company^ being a large and excellent one, as will be gathered by reference to the announcement in an other column. The Messrs FitzGerald

justly deserve the high reputation they enjoy as public entertainers, and their patrons may rely upon getting the full worth of their money. ■ The editor of the Federal Standard, (Chiltern) yesterday telegraphed us :—FitzGerald’s played yes terday, crowded tent; performance won derful ; many new and rare novelties.

School Board .Election.—Mr James

Cold well, J.P., returning-officer, gijes

notice of the triennial election of five members of the Shepparton Shire School Board of Advice, the date of which has been fixed for the 12th November, and of nominations by four o’clock on Tuesday,

27tb inst.

The Show Certificate.—The design of the show certificate executed by Mr John Longs taff, the artist, for the Shep parton Agricultural Society is a very fine

one. In the left-hand corner is seated a ! female figure holding laurel wreaths, while | overhead is a large spray of laurel, and at her side is a shield bearing the Australian arms. The design is a striking one, and has been well carried out, both by artist and lithographer. It may be mentioned that Mr Longslaff made no charge for his work, for which the best thanks of the society are certainly due to him.

Off to the West.—Mr John H. Noble, formerly secretary to the Shepparton District Butter Factory, leaves for Cooi gardio to-day. We wish him every luck, in whatever line of life he adopts on the western goldfields.

A Turf Disappointment.—The Mel bourne Cup favorite, Wallace, has been scratched for all engagements, owing to his having sprang the middle tendon of the near fore leg.

Shepparton Illustrated.—This week’s number of the Weekly Times contains several well-executed illustrations relating to the National Show held at Shepparton, with views of the butter factory and of Messrs Quiggin Bros.' establishment. Portraits are given of the president and secretary of the agricultural society (Messrs Clarke and Byas3), of Mr Thos. Geddes, and of members of the Mooroopua Hospital committee. The show pictures include the exhibit of ice made by the batter factory, Mr A. Halliday’s thorough bred stallion Cyclops, Mr D. Burgess’s Hereford bull, Mr G. Pagan’s Hereford cow, Mr D. Archibald’s draught stallion Wcodside Chief, the show grounds, the Governor's arrival, and watching the jumping.

The Benalla Show.—The above show, held on Wednesday and yesterday, was well attended, bntin point of number of exhibits was uot equal to previous exhibitions. Among the prize-takers in fat cattle was Mr H. Grattan, of Gowan gardie, who secured three first awards. The trials of hunters resulted as under: Lady’s huntei, C. Roach, 1; R. B. Vincent, 2. Maiden Hunter, R. B. Vin cent, 1 ; H. Roe, 2. Ponies over jumps, 3ft., E. Irving 1; D. M’Pherson, 2.

Municipal.—Mr Nugent enters upon his combined duties as shire secretary and rate-collector to-morrow. Messrs Strang ward and White, the Government and local auditors, proceed with the annual audit of the shire books and accounts on Monday. Special meetings of the council and water trust take place to-morrow, the former to confirm the improvement rate and the latter to deal with several important matters affecting the water supply which require immediate attention.

The Caulfield Cup.—The above event will be run to-morrow, and, with a start, we anticipate the result to be—Hopscotch, 1; Straightfire, 2; Rosella, 3.

Horology.—At the conclusion of next Monday evening’s business of the Loyal Moira Lodge, M.TJ.I.O.O.F., Bro. E. C Morris will deliver a lecture on “ Horology."

The Butter Factory.—Supplies to the Shepparton District Butter Factory are keeping up well, and the output of butter is consequently large. From the 1st September to the 12th inst. the factory has forwarded to Melbourne for export 53J tons of butter, of which 42 ton3 have been shipped to London, by the ss. Oroya, Orient. Oceana, Valetta and Lusitania. 11 tons 29 boxes (40 boxes go to a ton) are awaiting export, in Melbourne, and will be supplemented by five tons to be sent away from the factory to-day. The di rectors are about to break new ground by, erecting a creamery at Pine Lodge North, on land given for the purpose by Mr3 Moylan; tenders being returnable on the

23rd inst.

Shepparton Bowling Club.—The

official opening of the bowling season on the local green yesterday afternoon was one of the most successful social gatherings held in Shepparton. All sections of the community assembled, and had evidently made up their minds to have an enjoyable afternoon. The ladies were most promi nently to the fore in the whole arrange ments, and spared no trouble in catering for the pleasure of all. The members and their friends rolled up in force, the att* n dance numbering between GO and 70, and several new members were enrolled. After noon tea was indulged in by all. Every delicacy was provided, and with the refreshing luxuriance of the green and all the surroundings, including a large Japanese umbrella as a centre, made one imagine the assembly was a social afternoon tea "served up on one of the metropolitan

lawns. The committee deserve every credit for having the green in such excellent order, which was an occasion for many expressions of approval by all the players, and it seemed a pity that the fairer sex i could not join in the game. A friendly

contest between the president and vice president was indulged in (Miss Thorn rolling the first bowl) ; several recruits, so to speak, taking part, and acquitting themselves as veterans of past contests. Play was good throughout, the president (Hr Thorn, J.P.) scoring a wiu, which is a pleasant augury of his year of office, which promises much success. Thanks are due to the ladies for the excellent arrangements regarding the refreshments. May the club prosper is our heartiest wish, as a more pleasant means of recreation does uot

Shepparton Bicycle Sports.—Sale of Booths, Bicycle Sports, 9th November, at M’Bride, Martin and Co.’s Mart, Satur day next, 3 p.m.—[Advt.]

Inventions.—From Messrs. G. G. Turri and Co., patent agents, we are in receipt of an abridged edition of the Inventor’s Guide, which is printed in handy ami at tractive form, and contains many useful hints on the subject of securing patents, giving instructions, and other information

of value to the inventor.

A Frightful Tragedy.—A sheep farmer at Pine Valley, South Australia, named Joseph Thyer, killed his wife and five children on Sunday night, and then committed suicide liy hanging himself. Thyer committed the murders after his family had retired for the night. Thyer's two eldest sons were away from home on Sunday night, and on returning to Pine Valley on Monday morniug they were horrified to find that such a tragedy had been enacted. Thyer’s body was found hanging in the stockyard to the gallows.

A Road Fatality.—Mr Wm. Jackson, farmer, of Naringaningalook, met with a fatal accident on Saturday evening while driving home from Numurkah.

The Salvation &rmy.—A service of song, entitled "Little Eva,” will be ren dered in the local barracks of the Salvation Army on Sunday next, admission by silver coin. The self-denial week starts to morrow, and in aid of that fund a sale of gifts will be held in the barracks on the 2Gth inst.

The Village Settlement School —

Mr Bull has been appointed head-teacher of the Village Settlement Statr-school, near Shepparton, and entered upon his duties on Tuesday last.
